For the Scottish footballer, see [[Eddie O'Hara (footballer born 1935)]].}} {{Infobox MP | honorific-prefix = | name = Edward O'Hara | honorific-suffix =[[Member of Parliament|MP]] | image = | constituency_MP = [[Knowsley South (UK Parliament constituency)|Knowsley South]] | parliament = | majority = | predecessor = [[Sean Hughes (politician)|Sean Hughes]] | successor = constituency abolished | term_start = [[Knowsley South by-election, 1990|27 September 1990]] | term_end = [[United Kingdom general election, 2010|6 May 2010]] | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1937|10|1|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Bootle]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = [[United Kingdom|British]] | spouse = Lilian Hopkins | party = [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] | relations = | children = | residence = | alma_mater = [[Magdalen College, Oxford]] | occupation = | profession = | religion = | signature = | website = }} '''Edward O'Hara''' (born 1 October 1937) is a [[United Kingdom|British]] [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] politician who became the [[Member of Parliament]] (MP) for [[Knowsley South (UK Parliament constituency)|Knowsley South]] following the death of [[Sean Hughes (politician)|Sean Hughes]]. He held the seat from [[Knowsley South by-election, 1990|1990]] until [[United Kingdom general election, 2010|2010]] when the constituency was abolished. During this period his seat was considered the safest Labour seat in the country.<ref>Allegra Stratton, [http://www.guardian.co.uk/politics/2008/jul/26/gordonbrown.labour "20 MPs would survive swing repeat"], ''The Guardian'', July 26, 2008.</ref> He was chairman of the committee for technology and aerospace of the [[Western European Union]]<ref>http://209.85.129.132/search?q=cache:9qNFYkVjYMkJ:www.assembly-weu.org/en/documents/sessions_ordinaires/rpt/2007/1990.php+www.assembly-weu.org/+Axel+Fischer&hl=de&ct=clnk&cd=3&gl=de</ref> and was succeeded in 2009 by the German politician [[Axel Fischer (politician)|Axel Fischer]]. He left the House of Commons in 2010, after being defeated in the selection process to become Labour candidate for [[Knowsley (UK Parliament constituency)|Knowsley]] by fellow Labour MP [[George Howarth]].<ref>http://britainvotes.blogspot.co.uk/2010/05/knowsley-liverpool-and-st-helens.html</ref> ==Early life== O'Hara was born in [[Bootle]], near [[Liverpool]]. He was educated at the [[direct grant grammar school|direct-grant grammar]] [[Liverpool Collegiate School]], then [[Magdalen College, Oxford]], gaining an [[Master of Arts (Oxbridge and Dublin)|MA]] in Literae Humaniores, and the [[University of London]]. Before entering Parliament, Eddie was a councillor in [[Knowsley (village)|Knowsley]] and Chair of the Education Committee. He taught at [[Birkenhead School]] before lecturing at CF Mott College (became Liverpool Polytechnic) from 1970-5, at the City of Liverpool College of Higher Education from 1975–85, and at [[Liverpool John Moores University|Liverpool Polytechnic]] from 1985-90. == Personal life == He married Lilian Hopkins on September 11, 1962 in Bootle.
